caseTitle: AUGUSTUS KPAKPO BROWN v. S. BOSOMTWI & CO. LTD. & ADAM KWATE
summary: This 2002 Supreme Court of Ghana decision in CA No. 1/2001 involves a land dispute between Augustus Kpakpo Brown (plaintiff/appellant) and S. Bosomtwi & Co. Ltd. and Adam Kwatei Quartey (defendants). The plaintiff claimed ownership of land at Anyah, Greater Accra, seeking damages for gravel excavation and a perpetual injunction. The defendants countered that the land belonged to the Gbawe Kwatei Family, who had granted them rights. The trial court and Court of Appeal found in favor of the defendants, ruling the plaintiff failed to clearly identify and prove ownership of the land, particularly its western boundary. The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' concurrent findings, finding no miscarriage of justice, and dismissed the appeal.
rationaleHighlights: Plaintiff failed to clearly identify the western boundary of the claimed land
Plaintiff's evidence was inconsistent and confused regarding land description
Co-defendant provided clear description and evidence of overt acts of ownership
Exhibit CE1 (composite survey plan) defined the contested area
Concurrent findings by trial and appellate courts were supported by evidence
Supreme Court found no blunder or miscarriage of justice
Appellant's documents and prior judgments did not affect the core issues
Joinder of Anyaa Chief was vacated on appeal, weakening plaintiff's position
